message_1: Consider the elliptic curve E: y² = x³ + 3x + 5 defined over the field F₇ = {0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}. Let P = (2,0) and Q = (1,3) be points on the curve. Find the sum P + Q on the elliptic curve E.
message_2:
To find the sum P + Q on the elliptic curve E, we will use the formulas for adding points on an elliptic curve:

If P = (x1, y1) and Q = (x2, y2), then the sum R = P + Q = (x3, y3) can be computed as follows:

1. If P = O (the point at infinity) or Q = O, then P + Q = P or Q, respectively.
2. If x1 = x2 and y1 = -y2, then P + Q = O.
3. If P ≠ Q, then the slope λ = (y2 - y1) / (x2 - x1) and x3 = λ² - x1 - x2, y3 = λ(x1 - x3) - y1.
4. If P = Q, then the slope λ = (3x1² + a) / 2y1 and x3 = λ² - 2x1, y3 = λ(x1 - x3) - y1.

In our case, P = (2, 0) and Q = (1, 3), so P ≠ Q. We will use formula 3 to compute the sum:

First, we need to find the slope λ. Since we are working in the field F₇, all calculations will be done modulo 7:

λ = (y2 - y1) / (x2 - x1) = (3 - 0) / (1 - 2) = 3 / (-1) = 3 / 6 = 18 / 6 = 3 (mod 7)

Now, we can find the coordinates x3 and y3:

x3 = λ² - x1 - x2 = 3² - 2 - 1 = 9 - 2 - 1 = 6 (mod 7)

y3 = λ(x1 - x3) - y1 = 3(2 - 6) - 0 = 3(-4) = 3(3) = 9 = 2 (mod 7)

So, the sum P + Q = (x3, y3) = (6, 2).
